user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_get_timestamp:
```c
unsigned long long metal_get_timestamp(void)
{
	unsigned long long t = 0;
	struct timespec tp;
	int r;

	r = clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &tp);
	if (r == -1) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "clock_gettime failed!\n");
		return t;
	}
	t = tp.tv_sec * (NS_PER_S);
	t += tp.tv_nsec;

	return t;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_get_timestamp:
#define NS_PER_S (1000*1000*1000)
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The rest of the code in metal_get_timestamp and the NS_PER_S macro do not use compiler language extensions and therefore do not need investigation under MISRA C Rule 1.2. Specifically: - The function definition, local variable declarations, arithmetic on tp.tv_sec and tp.tv_nsec, and the return statement are standard C. - struct timespec, clock_gettime and CLOCK_MONOTONIC are POSIX APIs (library/OS interfaces), not compiler language extensions. - The NS_PER_S numeric macro is a plain preprocessor macro definition and not a compiler extension. Therefore only the provided macro definition needs further investigation for possible compiler-specific language extensions.
